comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
I have objections/concerns with this text.

The text states:

> "SD-JWT conceals only the values that aren't revealed. It does not
> meet standard security notations for anonymous credentials. In
> particular Verifiers and Issuers can know when they have seen the same
> credential no matter what fields have been opened, even none of them.
> This behavior may not accord with what users naively expect or are
> lead to expect from UX interactions and lead to them make choices they
> would not otherwise make. Workarounds such as issuing multiple
> credentials at once and using them only one time can help for keeping
> Verifiers from linking different showing.
> 

The text is confusing because it addresses two different topics:
Verifier-Verifier unlinkability and Issuer-Verifier Unlinkability. 

The last sentence means that problem can be addressed for the Verifier-Verifier unlinkability.
It is not necessary to use strong sentences like:

> " It does not meet standard security notations for anonymous credentials"

 which are not explained.

The sentence terminates with:

> but cannot work for Issuers.

This is the case for the Issuer-Verifier unlinkability.

At the moment there is text in section 10.1 that states :

> Issuer/Verifier unlinkability with a colluding or compromised Verifier cannot be achieved in salted-hash based selective disclosure approaches, such as SD-JWT, as the issued credential with the Issuer's signature is directly presented to the Verifier, who can forward it to the Issuer.

So the proposed text is redondant.

However, the use of the wording "colluding or compromised" does not seem to be appropriate.

The Issuer will not directly "collude" with a Verifier. However, a national authority might oblige a Verifier to reveal the SD-JWT that has been used for a given access and afterwards might also oblige the Issuer to reveal the identity of the End-User. 

This situation can only happen if both the Issuer and the Verifier memorize the SD-JWTs they have respectively issued or received.

So saying that "Issuer/Verifier unlinkability with a colluding or compromised Verifier cannot be achieved in salted-hash based selective disclosure approaches" is not appropriate.

Change into:

> Issuer/Verifier unlinkability can be achieved in salted-hash based selective disclosure approaches, such as SD-JWT, if the Verifier does not memorize the SD-JWTs that it has received.

> On the contrary, if the Verifier memorizes the SD-JWTs that it has received and if the Issuer memorizes the SD-JWTs that it has issued, then some authority might oblige a Verifier to reveal the SD-JWT that has been used for a given access and then oblige the Issuer of these SD-JWTs to reveal the identity of the End-Users.

The notions of "honest" or "dishonest" Verifier are not relevant. If a Verifier obeys to a local law, it should not be considered to be "dishonest".  By definition, an Issuer is trusted to be honest.

In section 10.1, the following text should be removed:

> In considering Issuer/Verifier unlinkability, it is important to note the potential for an asymmetric power dynamic between Issuers and Verifiers. This dynamic can compel an otherwise honest Verifier into collusion. For example, a governmental Issuer might have the authority to mandate that a Verifier report back information about the credentials presented to it. 
> Legal requirements could further enforce this, explicitly undermining Issuer/Verifier unlinkability. Similarly, a large service provider issuing credentials might implicitly pressure Verifiers into collusion by incentivizing participation in their larger ecosystem. 
> Deployers of SD-JWT must be aware of these potential power dynamics, mitigate them as much as possible, and/or make the risks transparent to the user.
> Contrary to that, Issuer/Verifier unlinkability with an honest Verifier can generally be achieved. 

If the Verifier does not memorize the SD-JWTs that it has received, then the risk can be avoided.

But there are also implications with section 10.2 , where the text states:

> All involved parties SHOULD store SD-JWTs containing privacy-sensitive data only for as long as needed, including in log files.
> 
> After Issuance, Issuers SHOULD NOT store the Issuer-signed JWT or the respective Disclosures if they contain privacy-sensitive data.

The term " privacy-sensitive data" is not defined.  A SD-JWT necessarily contains 'privacy-sensitive data'. 

The first sentence would prevent to support the Issuer/Verifier unlinkability that can be achieved. 
This first sentence should be removed.

The second sentence should be shortened and changed into:

> After Issuance, Issuers SHOULD NOT store the Issuer-signed JWT.

In section 10.2, the text continues with:

> Holders SHOULD store SD-JWTs only in encrypted form, and, wherever possible, use hardware-backed encryption in particular for the private Key Binding key. Decentralized storage of data, e.g., on user devices, SHOULD be preferred for user credentials over centralized storage. 
>
> Expired SD-JWTs SHOULD be deleted as soon as possible.
> 
> After Verification, Verifiers SHOULD NOT store the Issuer-signed JWT or the respective Disclosures if they contain privacy-sensitive data. It may be sufficient to store the result of the verification and any user data that is needed for the application.

The first recommendation is an implementation option. It should be removed.

The second recommendation might be misunderstood, as it would mean that Holders SHOULD NOT delete NON-EXPIRED SD-JWTs. It should be removed.

The third recommendation can also be misunderstood, as it would mean that Verifiers SHOULD store the Issuer-signed JWT or the respective Disclosures *if* they DO NOT contain privacy-sensitive data. 

It should be changed into:

> After Verification, Verifiers SHOULD NOT store the Issuer-signed JWT. It may be sufficient to store the result of the verification and any user data that is needed for the application.

This closes the loop: if neither the Issuer nor the Verifier stores the SD-JWT, then Issuer/Verifier unlinkability can be achieved.

comments.author: wbl
comments.body:
Denis, the goal of my contribution was to provide a simple summary paragraph of the entire set of considerations. In that sense it is redundant. We can add a citation to CL01, or some other paper that uses the standard security notion to explain it. I'm looking for a good one.

After that's done I expect there would need to be some editing to avoid excessive repetition.

I think a bunch of your comment is directed at the existing text rather than this PR. But I do want to say that we can't assume erasure happens. There's a whole bunch of places where data ends up in modern architectures that aren't really visible: HTTP logs, temporary files etc. We also don't assume that people will behave in security considerations: that's the joke in 3514, so guidance that only works if the verifier or issuer behave doesn't really do anything.

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
This paper (2001)  which is rather old is advocating a fully different technique which is not compatible with the protocol we are describing.

There exist similar techniques like BBS, BBS + or BBS # that we have deliberately not considered.

When using one-time use SD-JWTs, the same advantages that can be obtained by using these techniques can also be obtained using such SD-JWTs. 

The text you are proposing looks like a criticism:

> It does not meet standard security notations for anonymous credentials
> 
> This behavior may not accord with what users naively expect or are lead to expect from UX interactions and lead to them make choices they would not otherwise make.

The full text is confusing and misleading. 

It should not be included.

I propose the following title for it:

However, these two issues are strongly related.

The revised text that is being proposed is still misleading and the rational is mentioned in this "other" issue.

A sentence like 

> " This behavior may not accord with what users intuitively expect or are lead to expect from user interface interactions and lead to them make choices they would not otherwise make" 

is not understandable and should not be included into the document.

When using one-time use digital credentials, the same benefits as systems using ZKP can be obtained when considering the whole picture, I mean, including suspension and revocation checking.

We will be able to fix this issue 535 when the "other issue" will be fixed. So please , place this issue "on hold".

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
The text states:

>    SD-JWT only conceals the value of claims that are not revealed.  
>    It does not meet security notations for anonymous credentials [CL01].

[CL01] does not contain the words "notation", "anonymous"or "credentials".
Hence, this sentence is not understandable. Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

The text continues with:

>    In particular, colluding Verifiers and Issuers can know when they
>    have seen the same credential no matter what fields have been
>    disclosed, even when none have been disclosed.  This behavior may not
>    align with what users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect
>    from user interface interactions, potentially causing them to make
>    decisions they might not otherwise make. 
> 

It is not possible to understand which "behavior may not align with what users naturally anticipate or 
are guided to expect from user interface interactions".

It is not possible either to understand why this behavior will "potentially causing them to make decisions 
they might not otherwise make".

Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

The text continues with:

>    Workarounds such as batch  issuance, as described above, help with keeping Verifiers from
>    linking different presentations, but cannot work for Issuer/Verifier  unlinkability.  

This is untrue. If the Verifier deletes the presentations immediately after it has received them, 
presentations, including one-time-use presentations, cannot be used to link presentations with the Issuer.

Furthermore, if the Issuer is using a suspension / revocation mechanism different from the Status List Token, it does not need to use  "Referenced Tokens" and will still be able to revoke or suspend all the credentials that have been issued for the benefit of a given Holder. In such a case, the Issuer does not need to "remember" SD-JWTs that it has issued. If neither the Issuer, nor  the Verifier, keeps a record of respectively issued and received SD-JWTs, Issuer/Verifier  unlinkability can be "twice" achieved.

Since a specific mechanism to handle the suspension / revocation of a SD-JWT is outside the scope of this document, it is untrue to say that Issuer/Verifier  unlinkability "cannot work".

Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: Dennis, I once again would ask that you bring this to the list. This is not a great format for discussion and we need more eyes on it.

comments.author: wbl
comments.body:
> The text states:
> 
> > SD-JWT only conceals the value of claims that are not revealed.
> > It does not meet security notations for anonymous credentials [CL01].
> 
> [CL01] does not contain the words "notation", "anonymous"or "credentials". Hence, this sentence is not understandable. Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

Do you have a better reference for the security properties introduced there? This sentence now reads with s/notation/properties/.
> 
> The text continues with:
> 
> > In particular, colluding Verifiers and Issuers can know when they
> > have seen the same credential no matter what fields have been
> > disclosed, even when none have been disclosed.  This behavior may not
> > align with what users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect
> > from user interface interactions, potentially causing them to make
> > decisions they might not otherwise make.
> 
> It is not possible to understand which "behavior may not align with what users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect from user interface interactions".

Happy to rephrase. I don't think that sentence is beyond the bounds of comprehensibility. The point is the user doesn't expect that exposing age lets someone unambigiously link everywhere they have shown their age: they would expect that only their age be revealed.

> 
> It is not possible either to understand why this behavior will "potentially causing them to make decisions they might not otherwise make".

Because the risks are not necessarily the same as what they expect their decisions aren't the ones they would make if they understood them.

> 
> Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

Do you have suggestions for rephrasing.

> 
> The text continues with:
> 
> > Workarounds such as batch  issuance, as described above, help with keeping Verifiers from
> > linking different presentations, but cannot work for Issuer/Verifier  unlinkability.
> 
> This is untrue. If the Verifier deletes the presentations immediately after it has received them, presentations, including one-time-use presentations, cannot be used to link presentations with the Issuer.

There's no way for anyone to enforce that on the Verifier. It's also hard to ensure that data is erased even when trying: software stacks are complex.

> 
> Furthermore, if the Issuer is using a suspension / revocation mechanism different from the Status List Token, it does not need to use "Referenced Tokens" and will still be able to revoke or suspend all the credentials that have been issued for the benefit of a given Holder. In such a case, the Issuer does not need to "remember" SD-JWTs that it has issued. If neither the Issuer, nor the Verifier, keeps a record of respectively issued and received SD-JWTs, Issuer/Verifier unlinkability can be "twice" achieved.

We can't trust the Issuer doesn't record just because they don't have to. If men were angels, there would be no locksmiths.

> 
> Since a specific mechanism to handle the suspension / revocation of a SD-JWT is outside the scope of this document, it is untrue to say that Issuer/Verifier unlinkability "cannot work".

That is not what the sentence says. It says the mechanism in the document cannot guarantee it. Which is true: deletion on the part of other parties isn't enforced by anything here.

> 
> Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
The text states:

> SD-JWT only conceals the value of claims that are not revealed.
> It does not meet security notations for anonymous credentials [CL01].

[CL01] does not contain the words "notation", "anonymous"or "credentials". Hence, this sentence is not understandable. Either remove this sentence or rephrase it.

You responded:

> Do you have a better reference for the security properties introduced there? This sentence now reads with s/notation/properties/.

The same properties can be obtained with SD-JWT when using one-time-use SD-JWTs. So it is not necessary to argue that SD-JWT cannot meet properties that can be obtained using anonymous credentials.

There is no need to reference a paper.

The text continues with:

> In particular, colluding Verifiers and Issuers can know when they
> have seen the same credential no matter what fields have been
> disclosed, even when none have been disclosed. This behavior may not
> align with what users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect
> from user interface interactions, potentially causing them to make
> decisions they might not otherwise make.

I wrote: 

> 
It is not possible to understand which "behavior may not align with what users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect from user interface interactions".

You wrote: 

> Happy to rephrase. I don't think that sentence is beyond the bounds of comprehensibility. 
> The point is the user doesn't expect that exposing age lets someone unambigiously link everywhere they have shown their age: they would expect that only their age be revealed.

This argument is incorrect. If one-time-use SD-JWTs are used, then verifier/ verifier unlinkability is de facto supported.
It is not possible either to understand why this behavior will "potentially causing them to make decisions they might not otherwise make".

You wrote:

> Because the risks are not necessarily the same as what they expect their decisions aren't the ones they would make if they understood them.

Before an End-User presents a SD-JWT to a Verifier, the Verifier shall indicate which claims it would like to be revealed. The End-User shall either consent or refuse to consent. In addition, the End-User may be willing to only use one-time-use SD-JWTs. If the Holder is not configured in this way, the End-User should abort the transaction. 

You wrote:

> Do you have suggestions for rephrasing.

No. I only have a suggestion for deleting this sentence.


The text continues with:

> Workarounds such as batch issuance, as described above, help with keeping Verifiers from
> linking different presentations, but cannot work for Issuer/Verifier unlinkability.

I wrote:

> This is untrue. If the Verifier deletes the presentations immediately after it has received them, presentations, including one-time-use presentations, cannot be used to link presentations with the Issuer.

You wrote:

> There's no way for anyone to enforce that on the Verifier. It's also hard to ensure that data is erased even when trying: software stacks are complex.

The key wording "cannot work" is incorrect. Issuer/Verifier unlinkability *can* be supported in specific contexts. If a Verifier indicates in its practices statements that it deletes the received SD-JWTs once they are processed and if an auditor discovers later on that it does not do it, then it can go out of its business. The same applies for an Issuer.

I wrote:

> Furthermore, if the Issuer is using a suspension / revocation mechanism different from the Status List Token, it does not need to use "Referenced Tokens" and will still be able to revoke or suspend all the credentials that have been issued for the benefit of a given Holder. In such a case, the Issuer does not need to "remember" SD-JWTs that it has issued. If neither the Issuer, nor the Verifier, keeps a record of respectively issued and received SD-JWTs, Issuer/Verifier unlinkability can be "twice" achieved.

You wrote:

> We can't trust the Issuer doesn't record just because they don't have to. If men were angels, there would be no locksmiths.

See above, the case where an Issuer would lie.

I wrote:

> Since a specific mechanism to handle the suspension / revocation of a SD-JWT is outside the scope of this document, it is untrue to say that Issuer/Verifier unlinkability "cannot work".

You wrote:

> That is not what the sentence says. It says the mechanism in the document cannot guarantee it. Which is true: deletion on the part of other parties isn't enforced by anything here.

The sentence did not say " cannot guarantee it", but said "cannot work". This is not the same.

comments.author: wbl
comments.body:
On Thu, Jan 23, 2025, 2:08 AM Denisthemalice ***@***.***>
wrote:

> The text states:
>
> SD-JWT only conceals the value of claims that are not revealed.
> It does not meet security notations for anonymous credentials [CL01].
>
> [CL01] does not contain the words "notation", "anonymous"or "credentials".
> Hence, this sentence is not understandable. Either remove this sentence or
> rephrase it.
>
> You responded:
>
> Do you have a better reference for the security properties introduced
> there? This sentence now reads with s/notation/properties/.
>
> The same properties can be obtained with SD-JWT when using one-time-use
> SD-JWTs. So it is not necessary to argue that SD-JWT cannot meet properties
> that can be obtained using anonymous credentials.
>

Dennis,

This is completely wrong.

Your entire argument is premised on the idea that we can be assured the
Issuer will forget. Real attackers attack: they don't obey the rules.
That's why we have cryptography.

There is no way to enforce this sort of forgetting in the document, and if
you say we should use a TEE would need a massive amount of text saying how.
It would also create massive deployability issues.

In the real world enterprise and other architectures have a vast number of
places where data can be recorded. Even if an Issue wants to be sure they
forget, it's very hard to enforce.

> There is no need to reference a paper.
>
> The text continues with:
>
> In particular, colluding Verifiers and Issuers can know when they
> have seen the same credential no matter what fields have been
> disclosed, even when none have been disclosed. This behavior may not
> align with what users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect
> from user interface interactions, potentially causing them to make
> decisions they might not otherwise make.
>
> I wrote:
>
> It is not possible to understand which "behavior may not align with what
> users naturally anticipate or are guided to expect from user interface
> interactions".
>
> You wrote:
>
> Happy to rephrase. I don't think that sentence is beyond the bounds of
> comprehensibility.
> The point is the user doesn't expect that exposing age lets someone
> unambigiously link everywhere they have shown their age: they would expect
> that only their age be revealed.
>
> This argument is incorrect. If one-time-use SD-JWTs are used, then
> verifier/ verifier unlinkability is de facto supported.
> It is not possible either to understand why this behavior will
> "potentially causing them to make decisions they might not otherwise make".
>
> You wrote:
>
> Because the risks are not necessarily the same as what they expect their
> decisions aren't the ones they would make if they understood them.
>
> Before an End-User presents a SD-JWT to a Verifier, the Verifier shall
> indicate which claims it would like to be revealed. The End-User shall
> either consent or refuse to consent. In addition, the End-User may be
> willing to only use one-time-use SD-JWTs. If the Holder is not configured
> in this way, the End-User should abort the transaction.
>
> You wrote:
>
> Do you have suggestions for rephrasing.
>
> No. I only have a suggestion for deleting this sentence.
>
> The text continues with:
>
> Workarounds such as batch issuance, as described above, help with keeping
> Verifiers from
> linking different presentations, but cannot work for Issuer/Verifier
> unlinkability.
>
> I wrote:
>
> This is untrue. If the Verifier deletes the presentations immediately
> after it has received them, presentations, including one-time-use
> presentations, cannot be used to link presentations with the Issuer.
>
> You wrote:
>
> There's no way for anyone to enforce that on the Verifier. It's also hard
> to ensure that data is erased even when trying: software stacks are complex.
>
> The key wording "cannot work" is incorrect. Issuer/Verifier unlinkability
> *can* be supported in specific contexts. If a Verifier indicates in its
> practices statements that it deletes the received SD-JWTs once they are
> processed and if an auditor discovers later on that it does not do it, then
> it can go out of its business. The same applies for an Issuer.
>
> I wrote:
>
> Furthermore, if the Issuer is using a suspension / revocation mechanism
> different from the Status List Token, it does not need to use "Referenced
> Tokens" and will still be able to revoke or suspend all the credentials
> that have been issued for the benefit of a given Holder. In such a case,
> the Issuer does not need to "remember" SD-JWTs that it has issued. If
> neither the Issuer, nor the Verifier, keeps a record of respectively issued
> and received SD-JWTs, Issuer/Verifier unlinkability can be "twice" achieved.
>
> You wrote:
>
> We can't trust the Issuer doesn't record just because they don't have to.
> If men were angels, there would be no locksmiths.
>
> See above, the case where an Issuer would lie.
>
> I wrote:
>
> Since a specific mechanism to handle the suspension / revocation of a
> SD-JWT is outside the scope of this document, it is untrue to say that
> Issuer/Verifier unlinkability "cannot work".
>
> You wrote:
>
> That is not what the sentence says. It says the mechanism in the document
> cannot guarantee it. Which is true: deletion on the part of other parties
> isn't enforced by anything here.
>
> The sentence did not say " cannot guarantee it", but said "cannot work".
> This is not the same.
>
> —

> <https://github.com/oauth-wg/oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt/pull/535#issuecomment-2609394088>,
> or unsubscribe

> .

> ***@***.***>

comments.author: Denisthemalice
comments.body:
Section 10.2 (Storage of User Data) states: 

> All involved parties SHOULD NOT store SD-JWTs longer than strictly needed, including in log files.

Depending upon the context of use, this recommendation should or should not be followed since there exist cases where the Issuer-Verifier unlinkability property will prevent fighting against crime or money laundering.

In these cases, the Verifier should not memorize the whole SD-JWTs that it receives, but a unique reference specific to the SD-JWT together with an identifier of the Issuer. Some authority might request to a Verifier to reveal the identifier of the Issuer and this unique reference. Then after, the authority might communicate it to the Issuer and request the Issuer to reveal the identity of the End-User corresponding to that unique reference.

While technically, the Issuer-Verifier unlinkability property sounds good from a privacy point  of view, the privacy of the individuals needs to be balanced against the interests of governments or of international organizations, like Interpol, to fight against crime or money laundering.

```suggestion
SD-JWT only conceals the value of claims that are not revealed.
It does not provide Issuer/Verifier unlinkability without constraints
as schemes using zero-knowledge protocols do (for example, [@?CL01]). In
particular, entities with access to the SD-JWTs and their presentations can know when they have seen the same

This behavior may not accord with what users intuitively expect or are
```

Brian, I don't quite understand your question. Yes, if every credential has a unique serial number that's always revealed, you have a problem. But you don't have more problems than that: they simulate ideal functionality.

I do think taking out "It does not meet standard security notations for anonymous credentials." and saying some schemes meet tighter notions is a bad idea. The whole point is that every application we've been discussing for the past quarter century won't automatically work with this scheme: that we need to signpost we didn't do the right thing here. I don't think Daniel's suggestion does that as strongly. I do like changing to entity in the rest of the text.

```suggestion
   1. A salt value. MUST be a string. See (#salt-entropy) for security considerations. To achieve recommended entropy of the salt, the Issuer can base64url-encode 128 bits of cryptographically secure random data, producing a string. The salt value MUST be unique for each claim that is to be selectively disclosed. The Issuer MUST NOT reveal the salt value to any party other than the Holder.
```
I still think some kind of allowance to reasonably allow for different implementation choices like order of some steps or use of different intermediate data structures than what's implied.

This covers one part of the discuss, but I still want to chat about the scenario described here:

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/oauth/yVX3ku5P4O-3gLinWfAsj86Lj8g/

> A relying party MUST reject SD-JWT+KB when SD-JWT or KB-JWT contain audience values and none of the audience  values are associated with the relying party.

Higher bandwidth should resolve this, and its possible this is obvious to folks already, and so redundant to the current requirements.

comments.author: bc-pi
comments.body: Yep, I noted our coming higher bandwidth discussion https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/oauth/kfFRfttW9kLhvQ0lyR6oMnuxrMQ/

comments.author: danielfett
comments.body: Approved, posthumously.
